title: Soroban Research: What the Scientific Studies Actually Show
description: A review of academic research on soroban and mental math training – what's proven and what's not.

content.intro: There's a lot of marketing hype about soroban. But what does actual research say? Let's look at the evidence.

sections.text: Multiple studies confirm soroban training significantly improves mental calculation speed and accuracy. This is the core, well-proven benefit.
A 2019 meta-analysis of 18 studies found soroban training improved arithmetic skills by an average of 0.65 standard deviations – a moderate to large effect.

Brain imaging studies show soroban experts use different brain regions than non-experts. They process numbers more like spatial images, engaging visual working memory. Training appears to strengthen these pathways.
Research shows soroban users develop stronger intuitive understanding of quantities and place value – what researchers call "number sense."
Some studies claim soroban raises IQ. The evidence is weak. Better interpretation: soroban may improve specific cognitive skills that overlap with some IQ subtests, not general intelligence.
Does soroban help with subjects besides math? Evidence is limited. Some studies show improvements in concentration and focus that may help broadly, but direct transfer is not proven.
How long do benefits last after stopping practice? Limited research on this. Anecdotally, skills decline without practice but don't disappear completely.

items: "Soroban makes children geniuses" – no evidence for this
"Soroban is better than all other math methods" – it's one good tool among many
"2 weeks of soroban will transform your child" – benefits require sustained practice

sections.text: What This Means for Parents & Teachers

items: Soroban IS effective for mental math – this is proven
It MAY have broader cognitive benefits – plausible but not certain
It's NOT magic – requires consistent practice over months/years
It's a tool, not a complete curriculum
Marketing claims often exceed what research supports

sections.text: Evaluate soroban for what it definitely does: build mental math and number sense. That alone is valuable enough.

faq.question: Is soroban research conducted mostly in Asia?
faq.answer: Yes, most research is from Japan, China, Korea, and India. Some Western studies exist. Methods used in Asia aren't always culturally transferable.

faq.question: Are there any negative studies?
faq.answer: A few studies show no significant effect, usually with short interventions (weeks vs. months). The key variable seems to be duration and consistency of practice.

faq.question: What research gaps exist?
faq.answer: Long-term follow-up studies, comparisons to other mental math methods, optimal starting age – all need more research.
